body.p: I have at the request of old man Samuel Miles consented to present to Governor Bramlette a petition for the parddon of his son William Miles who is stands indicted in the Ballard Circuit Court for Robbery of McCutchen, Dalton & Brummall. As you were acting as atty for the Commonwealth when the trial of the real perpetrators were tried ^was had^ and have heard all the evidence on two defferent occasions I determined before I made any application to ask that you would give to me over your own signature a statement of the evidence and your recollection of who was certainly implicated and how far it involved William Miles --

I am induced to press for petition
the Governor for a pardon at this time in advance of a trial for several reasons the principal of which however are, 1st that the old man his father has paid for him upwards of a thousand dollars and which has nearly beggared him and unless Bill can come home and assist him on the farm he can never recuperate and that William is willing and anxious to do so and thus by his work repay to his father in a great measure what he has caused him to pay out. The remaining and strong reason is that William Miles comes home out of the Federal army where I learn he has deported himself well as a soldier. The persons who will as a matter of Course be regarded as his prosecutors were some of them actually engaged and others favorable to the success of the Southern army You know sir how
anxious all of us are and with what solicitude we hope shaped our action to prevent all chances of collision or the happening of any thing that might serve to rip up old sores -- If this man in your opinion is really guilty and should be convicted and is not the victim of his confidence in others who led him even as far astray as he did go then I will not ask you to unite with me in asking Govr Bramlette to interpose otherwise I hope you will and that you will write me a reply to this which I may be at liberty to enclose to the Governor for his consideration. What good can come of prosecuting a man who was not present at any of the robberies -- who evidently seperated ^himself^ from those who have been convicted as the robbers when that prosecution might
serve to revive in all its bitterness the angry passions of the past and throw again into turbulence and passion heated state of a year or two past a whole community now in concord & harmony. Please consider of these things and send me your reply at your earliest convenience
